replies.text:
@FakeSchrodingersCat The issue with Marxism is that in every single circumstance that it's been tried, and the idea of collectivism dehumanizes the entire society. 

As such, there have been genocides, famines, as well as a tattletale culture that leaves everyone untrustworthy of one another out of fear.

Nazis were mass murdering psychopaths, but so are communist leaders.

There's a very good reason people escape communist countries, and people who grow up in communist/former communist countries are extremely opposed to communism because they've already lived in that hell. That's not a coincidence, either. Over the last century, there have been dozens of failed communist countries, and in every single circumstance, it has caused widespread suffering on the population.

This leads me to that second point - collectivism. Collectivism, in essence, means that the group, party, or idea, should come first. Before the individual good, or individual rights, to be specific. This was very much a thing before the Renaissance in the 16th century, as well as the Industrialization of the world. The "peasant" class, which was nearly everyone, were disposable cannon fodder for the upper castes of society. The lives of the poor mattered little to the leaders, generally.

Now, both communism and Nazism practiced collectivism, as it strips away individual identity and individual rights in favor for adherence to an ideology, and bowing before a large, totalitarian government. Why is this bad? 

"The common good should come before the individual good." - Adolf Hitler

This evil message connects perfectly with collectivism, and we're even seeing it today. Collectivism, in Essence, says the common good should come before your individual well-being, and as the government has the say over what is "good" or not,  the people, who have very little power, are mere pawns on a chess board, and the government decides who gets to live or die. 

In turn, this dehumanizes all of society, as their individual right to live, as it conflicts with the "party" and their belief that your well-being is in opposition to their "greater good".

And for further knowledge, feel free to listen to former KGB Agent Yuri Bezmenov (or however you spell it) talk about the Marxist subversion through indoctrination through education by manipulating how people think.

replies.author: @FakeSchrodingersCat
replies.text:
@aquicklad972 ‚Äã The problem is your idea of Communism and mine are different the same with our definitions of Marxism and even collectivism.  

You equate these to the Leninist versions which is top down state controlled totalitarian system while I believe in bottom up grass root organizations.  

To me the self proclaimed state communism of places like the soviet union hold as much weight as countries like North Korea declaring themselves democracies.  Russia might have started out as a communist revolution but that died very quickly as the Bolsheviks murdered all opposition who threatened their power, after which they were not communist or socialists or even collectivists they were simply another totalitarian state that happened to use the window dressing of Marx rather then Capitalism or Nietzsche or Christianity or Hereditary right to justify their rule.

As for collectivism my idea of what that means is not an imposed state where if you mess up I am also punished for it, that is not collectivism even if the Soviets and Nazis decided to use that label.  Collectivism as described by Marx is the model of the trade union where people agree to collectively work together to bargain for fair and equal wages and working conditions.  Or when a group of farmers collectively agree to pool their labor and harvests.  Or the shops where rent is split and tools are shared so that each craftman does not need to duplicate every item and expense.  The main thing is it is voluntary and it a collective pooling of resources and risks not blame and punishment.

The problem is you are taking a very specific corruption of these terms and then assuming that the corruption was actually the desired result.  Marx would have been absolutely livid that the Soviets or Chinese or North Koreans call themselves communists because they break every specific point not to mention the very spirit of his ideals.

replies.text:
@arsenelupin123 There's an interesting effect the lack of this realization has on understanding history. That is to say, both the Communist Party of China and the Nationalist Party of China are _westernization_ movements. It speaks a lot to the sentiments at the time among locals regarding the value of old Chinese cultural artifacts and teachings that these two parties were the only major choices that people supported. Arguments about how the Cultural Revolution would not have happened if the Nationalists were in power generally ignore the fact that the entire populace was sick and tired of "the old ways."

It behooves us to remember that Marxism is a Western ideology. And in doing so, we must consider that if either party of China were to accomplish its ideological goals, the cultural artifacts of the old China would stand in the way. The devil would be in the details as to what extent destruction would happen, but undoubtedly the tide of history would still flow against preservation of historical artifacts.

_jeff _ I don't know if you're trolling, but here's my two cents anyway:
It doesn't make sense to outline a thing one would call "THE" cultural narrative. The idea that there is a prevailing cultural narrative which happens to be directly in conflict with your own worldview is a convenient farce born out of sheer myopia and confirmation bias (It's also an obvious dogwhistle). There are people with ideas and reasons for having those ideas. A lot of people with capital share similar ideas, which usually tend to land between the center and the far right. I would argue that if I were to pin down a definitive "cultural narrative", it would land a lot closer to Stephan Molyneux than you would probably want to admit. Reactionaries tend to see the world through the lens of their own persecution complex, and as such construct a narrative to suit their belief that they're deviant somehow.

replies.author: @darthhatespeech5329
replies.text:
@dwagon6706 
"Do you believe That racism exists" 

Yes, racism is a prejudice that results from stereotypes, which in turn are a result of our in- and out-group behavior.


"Do you believe that race is (with humans) isn‚Äôt based on biological truth but fully made up and has  random categories (a social construct)"

No, the problem is that the concept of race in relation to humans is too associated with racism.
Whether we call it phenotype, or race. Both mean differences between people such as bone structure, face shape and skin color that is inherited. Not naming these differences just in humans, means not naming things out of fear. Neither the breeding aspect nor the insufficient genetic difference are valid counter arguments. Which doesn't mean that people of different races are worth different amounts. And that's actually where the fear of this designation breaks.
 

"Do you believe that various forms of prejudice combined might lead to someone facing more or less unique kinds of discrimination (example: black nem have the prejudice of being criminals and violent. with blank women or white men these prejudices are less common)"

It can lead to this, but it doesn't have to.
It depends on whether there are prejudices from which the person's characteristics are inferred, or whether there are stereotypes that assign existing facts to corresponding groups of people. And so it is based on the individual who consciously has generalized prejudices, refuses to recognize factual patterns, or recognizes patterns without completely generalising.
So yes and no. Above all, it also depends on the definition of racism. The universal definition, or the intersectional transfiguration of racism.

replies.author: @johnschwartz1641
replies.text:
Nathan Bear, even if we accept that humans were sufficiently isolated for long enough for (I assume personality) traits to diverge between populations, there isn't much evidence that there would be an evolutionary advantage for any particular traits.

Think of it this way: Lactase persistence is highly advantageous for people with access to milk producing livestock, because it allows for easier nutrition. It evolved sometime in the past several thousand years, and it spread rapidly because of the advantage it gave. Skin and eye pigmentation has differing advantages depending on exposure to sunlight, and we see how that has resulted in different skin colors for modern humans. 

There is however, no proof that certain personality traits or distributions of personality traits would give different advantages for populations in different areas. e.g. There's no reason to believe that humans in East Asia are better off with lower or higher neuroticism than humans in South America, or that humans in Europe should have any difference in openness from those in North America. So why would the populations evolve differently if they're all under the same pressures?

Basically in order for populations to have different rates of expression for traits, there needs to be some sort of reason. Birds might get a tougher beak to crack certain nuts, or they might learn to swim to get at fish that would otherwise be unattainable. Humans would need a reason to express differences in traits that map on to political temperament.

The rates of these traits being selected for don't have to be high to begin with, there's enough generations for it to add up. My solution to this is to sit down and get a good image of the evolutionary history of as many distinct groups as possible and craft political systems to suit it.

replies.text:
Exactly. Nobody calls their worldview, "cultural Marxism." What so many of these people are actually criticizing isn't even the Frankfurt School. (As far as I understand it, The Frankfurt School is the alternative to cultivation theory who argue that media is a reflection of society rather than society being shaped by the media.) They're the originators of critical theory but you'd need to make multiple jumps across dozens of philosophers who all disagree with one another to reach intersectional feminism.

Who the right are actually criticizing are people like Catherine MacKinnon and bell hooks who are both thinkers who go as far to the left as possible. Their ideas have been around academia for decades but they weren't taken seriously outside of first-year college English programs. Their views didn't go mainstream until various Tumblr users weaponized those views. Many of those accounts were actually fake user accounts signal boosting them who came from Stormfront and 4Chan's /pol/ board. Some of hashtags were even created by the extreme-right. (EndFathersDay being one of them.) The goal was to make the left so utterly insufferable that extreme-right ideas would somehow be socially acceptable and people like Nigel Farage, Donald Trump, Geert Wilders, etc wouldn't appear as scary.

This rabbithole goes deeper and involves, Putin, Wikileaks, etc but you're on the right track.

Cultural marxism is simply the recognition that many modern leftists/neo-marxists apply marxist thinking to other identity groups:

oppressor group | oppressed group

bourgeoisie | proletariat      (the standard marxist identity groups)
white | non-white
men | women

cis | trans
western | non-western
christian | non-christain
able | disabled

Cultural marxism is not a conspiracy, and it is not pushed by any particular group, it exists because many people believe in it and push its ideas.  It doesn't seek to destroy the west in principle, but that is what it may be doing in practice.  It is the leftist form of identity politics.

replies.author: @brisca1668
replies.text:
@CG0077 Indeed, there is no objective basis for my subjective values. Honestly i don`t think any other position than nihilism is logically coherent, mainly because of regress ad infinitum (basically skepticism applied to values). Are subjective values inherently self-delusional? I`d argue not, since i am aware that there is no transcendent grounding for them. You can see it similar to Kantian postulates, but applied to existential questions (and, in my case, both the question of objective morality and our access to definitive truths of any kind): I am aware that i cannot prove this, but i still act as if it was true, knowing that it, objectively, is not. 
Not that it matters if i deceive myself, since objective morality doesn`t exist anyway. 

In case you are interested in what postulates i have set for myself:

Human flourishing/well-being is positive.
Logic is true.
The world and myself, and other beings exist (roughly) as i empirically perceive it.
Time exists.

And probably a few more that i haven`t explicitly formulated/noticed yet. Within those assumptions i have come to the conclusion that a certain type of communism is the best political system. 


@chrusto I never said that though. I am not a Hegelian (but Marxists, in my understanding, generally aren`t since among other things they are materialists, its just that marx was influenced by hegel and was a Left Wing Hegelian for a while), not an existentialist (i don`t believe in free will) and not a postmodernist (although strongly influenced by them). I am a Postmarxist, meaning that there are aspects of Marxist philosophy that i see as wrong and some that i see as correct. And i am a nihilist, rejecting objective values. If i had to name a philosopher that influenced my worldview most, its probably David Hume.

Your assertion that you cannot be Hegelian and nihilistic at the same time is correct though, but the same is true for being Hegelian and existentialist, and in my understanding being a Hegelian postmodernist requires serious mental gymnastics (i am aware of the irony in this statement).  
Can somebody enlighten me if you can be a nihilistic existentialist though? Wouldn`t that just make you a nihilist?

replies.author: @CG0077
replies.text: @Brisca Ahh, I think youre a fictionalist rather than a Nihilist then.  A fictionalist holds that whilst there may be no 'objective' or 'true' morality, holds that they are a useful fiction.  A lie for the sake of whatever values you 'subjectively' determine them to be.  A nihilist would make the same move to abandoning 'objective' morality but (in my estimation) also abandons 'subjective' morality in the same move.

replies.author: @brisca1668
replies.text:
@CG0077 I am a fictionalist in the sense that you described, but that doesn`t mean i am not a nihilist. 
(Moral) fictionalism refers to a meta-ethical position that argues that claims in discourse should be taken as true or false, but the aim of discourse is not actually truth but some other virtue. So i am fictionalist in the sense that i think discourse cannot and should not aim for absolute truth, but for "truth within a system of premises" as you could put it.
A more accurate term would be meta-ethical moral relativist though.

I am however a nihilist in several forms, since 
i don`t believe in any intrinsic meaning/value of life (like an existentialist, but they have a few other characteristics) 
i don`t believe that any certain knowledge is possible for humans (which is a form of skepticism) 
i don`t believe that moral judgements can be objectively true or false without any premises (=amoralism,  meta- ethical moral relativism) 
which is why i generally just use the umbrella term over specifying the 3 types of nihilism i adhere to.

But as i have stated before, i have retained being able to enjoy debate (or discourse, like this one) through just making a few random assumptions without claim to objective truth.

Brisca also, Hegelian philosophy is the basis of marxism, and has a fundamental belief in platonic realism. 

Sartre‚Äôs statement (which originated in Heidegger) of ‚ÄúExistence precedes essence‚Äù is the fundamental to most existentialist theory.
However hegel, being essentialist, would have disagreed and asserted that ‚ÄúEssence precedes existence‚Äù.

Also Hegel believed that freedom in totality was a complicated mix of either free will and determination, when Sartre asserted a true polarity: either we are fully free or completely predetermined.

These philosophies do not combine.

replies.text:
@cito2820 Didnt see that, sorry for the late response


Some marxists (althusser for example) reject hegelianism completely, some only take some aspects (Marx himself) and some see Marxism as the natural extension of hegelianism (me)
Calling oneself a "hegelian" when your philosophy is largely influenced by hegelian dialectics has been common practice for centuries (just look at the young hegelian movement). Im a hegelian in the same way stirner was: i use hegelian dialectics and agree with most of his philosophical positions, but strongly disagree with his conclusions. (For example, i am idealist only in its weakest, kantian definition, and materialist for all practical purposes)



Its true that existentialism and "orthodox" hegelianism are contradictory, but i am a hegelian in the same way that satre himself and also heidegger were hegelians (id advise you to read satres dialectical reason and heideggers lectures on hegel if you are interested)


Im also technically absurdist and not existentialist, so i dont believe in free will full stop, but the distinction between camus and satre was more personal than philosophical imo

Someone with a background in philosophy here. You're partially right about the misrepresentation, in particular your point that the alt-right rhetoric mashes (neo)marxism, postmodernism, nihilism, and critical theory, even though these denote very distinct bodies of work and movements, often mutually exclusive ones. As for the specifics, well there's a lot a lot more to be said but a youtube comment can't really cover it. I'm thinking about starting a video series of my own, comparing some alt-right definitions and analyses of things like postmodernism, the frankfurter schule and neomarxism in general against *ahem* the actual historical and philosophical developments, where they came from, what they did and what influence they've actually had on today's political discourse.

author: @tomschmidt5946
text:
Philosophy student at the Geothe University (in Frankfurt) here, who is interested in the Frankfurt School (and has recently written a final on Haberma√ü). Basically the Frankfurt School developed critical theory as a tool to analyse our current (CAPITALIST) society. In their analysis they intially used many of the central assumptions of Marxism, but abandoned or fundamentally changed many of them later on. I can't and won't give a definitive judgement upon the moral beliefs of Adorno, Horkheimer or Haberma√ü since I'm only really starting out my journey into their teachings. But when I view the world through the lense of critical theory there is only one moral belief that could be interpreted as """communist""": That the superiority of the wealthy is not inherently good, but must justify itself through its contribution to the common good.

And to be honest I don't think that position is either radical nor unreasonable.

replies.author: @samanthafoxxy8284
replies.text:
Don't you think Adorno/horkheimer are a bit condencending towards the people exploited under capital? 

In my opinion, the classical marxist conflict worldview is much more rooted in reality than the idea that conflicts of interest are passible to resolution, as Habermas/Rawls want. I cannot see where on earth a "Kantian Republicanism" can ever be a reality when all you have is i-rationality and non-discoursive political fights... Eliminating conflict is a highway ticket to fascism, as we have seen (the great party of the centre is a dangerous dream). Not to mention rational agreements can only be possible inside institutions, never between real popular upheavels and the State (legal products need institutional routes such as syndicalism for instance). Even think about the liquid modernity presented by Zygmunt Bauman and the impossibility of discoursive agreements between closed communities (Lyotard) in today's digital framework and social medias. Without conflict, democracies are doomed to fail or give up to the populist agenda, not to mention the fascists.

author: @chrisball3778
text: The biggest problem with equating Marxism and Postmodernism, is that Postmodernism was developed specifically as a way to criticise 'structuralist' theories, specifically including Marxism. They have very little at all in common and have always existed in opposition to eachother. Saying 'Postmodern Marsixm' is sort of like saying 'Right-wing leftism'. Ironically, the only people capable of concocting such a ridiculously contrived idea would be Postmodernists themselves, who sometimes like to entertain contradictory positions in order to 'deconstruct metanarratives'. Despite ostensibly slating Postmodernism every chance he gets, Jordan Peterson  sounds an awful lot like a Postmodernist at times.

replies.text:
"i watched this entire shitfest and it can be summed up as "all these people agree with hitler and they dont know it, its all antisemitsm i tell you""
Except he addressed this specifically. It's not that they're necessarily antisemitic they just don't know how to explain what they see outside of this. Just watch this -> 13:20 bit again.
The point isn't that they're nazis at all. It's that they've taken a boogie man that part of their audience has little trouble agreeing with. Then they give it new paint to appeal to the rest. 
"Now you may have seen all the anti white bullshit coming out of universities but there is definitely no such thing as cultural marxism."
Why does it have to be cultural marxism? Can't it just be anti-white bullshit? Show the connection. You wouldn't want to make the mistake of condemning any left-wing suggestion as communism right? Also consider placing this later in your post because I'm certain you alienated almost all of your readers. 
"the left basicly calls everything "Far right nazi""
The attention grabbing nature of media now practically enforces hyperbole. It's what people click on very few give attention to "Modest opinion and detailed explanation of circumstance" vs "Extraordinary other claims YOU are a big problem". So the crazies get loud. It doesn't help matters that if you go to practically any of the comments section for these people they have both mocking and condescending attitudes to plenty of things nazi's would be strongly opposed even if it'd be extreme to say anyone holding those beliefs is a nazi. Looking at things from the perspective of quantity of attention is not a good way to build an accurate image of general opinion within a group. It's as bad as believing (any) media representation of incidents over statistics.

What I could see you disagreeing with in a perfectly reasonable way is the labels of far right and far left. They're incredibly relative and give very little information to the reader. The use of the way far gives you a broad range of people potentially accepting your view so the content can appeal to more people. Because most people don't consider themselves extreme so they're not directly offended. Now Three Arrows address specific groups of 'followers' here so it's not that ambiguous. Labels are an effective tool of grouping opinions and avoiding to address them all. Everyone is at fault of doing this. This video doesn't exactly leave you with much respect for the far right as a group even if there's completely orthogonal topics.
But it's much to ask of Three Arrows to manage a presentation that responds to a group issue in a way that doesn't leave the viewer thinking of them as a group of opinion or people. You have to read for intent.

Cultural Marxism isn't a conspiracy. It is just a bunch of movements encouraged by Jews pursuing their interests with all the tools at their disposal.  There are no secret meetings with sneaky Jews hunched over tables in dark rooms planning the revolution...

But Jews have been 3 % of the US population but up to 30% positions of power. Same in Europe... financial, academic , cultural, artistic. If they calculated that applying pressure to fault lines that already existed.... racial inequality, feminism, mass immigration...  would weaken their powerful white Christian rivals, then of course they would do it. They don't control these movements but they helped get them up and running with financial, academic, media and artistic support.  Who could blame them for pursuing their interests. There is no doubt that living in a Western country now is much better for Jews than it used to be. 

Some of these changes have been good, like stopping discrimination against gays and minorities , but the destruction of the family has hurt everyone . Blacks more so than whites.  Three Arrows just ignores this completely.

He says there is nothing written by the Frankfurt school that can be linked to Cultural Marxism but a simple google search finds Max Horkheimer from the Frankfurt school quoted as saying "the root of Nazism is the family"

Wilhelm Reich said  "The organized religious mysticism of Christianity was an element of the authoritarian family that led to Fascism."
"The patriarchal power in and outside of man was to be dethroned."
"Revolutionary sexual politics would mean the complete collapse of authoritarian ideology."

Theodor Adorno's book "Authoritarian Personality was one of the important books forming the basis of Critical Theory, which was essentially  destructive  criticism  of  the  main  elements  of  Western  culture,  including Christianity,  capitalism,  authority,  the  family,  patriarchy,  hierarchy, morality,  tradition, sexual restraint, loyalty, patriotism, nationalism, heredity, ethnocentrism, convention and conservatism .  The grand scheme of Adorno‚Äôs message, along with his other co-conspirators, was to fundamentally rearrange the values of Western nations so that school children and youth would become walking mouthpieces of the Frankfurt school revolutionary characters, thereby bringing about the new man."

replies.text:
We don't need to fear all immigrants, though they certainly aren't all the poor victims the media makes them out to be, especially not the illegal immigrants that aren't actual refugees and behave very poorly in turn for the kindness many European countries show them.

And you think these countries were any better before colonialism? There are a few countries that were really messed up by colonialism, India and Native American cultures would come to mind. These had actual cultures that would have been worth preserving and mostly got destroyed by colonialism, yes. However, many countries in Africa were in a terrible state before colonialism and international slave trade even started. Colonialism didn't change very much in many African countries, only who was in charge of the atrocities. Colonialism was nothing to be proud of, certainly, but it wasn't much worse than the circumstances before it and improved a lot of things by sharing modern technology. Furthermore, few European countries actively participated in colonialism, it was mostly Britain, Spain, Portugal and France, to some degree Prussia, the Netherlands, the US and some others. You could make an argument for the affected countries and which countries the colonised, but not for countries that never had a colony in Africa or Asia to begin with. Claiming Europe or the US have to own up for this is the wrong approach, if you really wanted to dig into the history of these things, most of which is around 100 years back already. Even then, it was not a democratically elected decision and now the general population should own up for the decisions of nobility and the few.

Sorry, but many of these countries can't be described in any other way, by modern standards. Take a look at how things are going there, even after colonialism is mostly over and done with. There's still genocides going on, persecution and all of those abhorrent things, many of which Europe had very little to do with. They have to fix their own countries, that is the only solution. replies.text:
Justin Pharand ‚Äúeveryone has a home‚Äù?? tell that to the nearly 2000 homeless people in my city alone, some of whom i personally see begging on busy intersections daily. they certainly did not get there by choice. unless you chalk up every single instance of homelessness as a personal failing‚Äî a willing refusal to engage sufficiently in business to make a living wage‚Äî instead of accepting that MANY factors (such as disability, debt, class, employability, and economic crashes outside of any one person‚Äôs control) have a great impact on how much opportunity someone is afforded... well, somewhere deep down you have to understand that capitalism does not provide for everyone.

in fact, it CANNOT provide for everyone. it relies on there being an underclass. resources flow upwards, the rich encouraged by the system to seek ever more profit. this is how you get politicians backed by oil companies that refuse to enact any policy that might detriment the people putting money in their pockets, out of fear that the support will be withdrawn. under capitalism, EVERYTHING comes down to profit. human lives are only worth as much as they can be wrung out for cash.

it may have been a step up from feudalism, but in the modern day, with its pervasive pressure over everything we do... it‚Äôs hard to even imagine a life outside capitalism and classism, a life free from meaningless drudgery in pursuit of scraps from those just a few steps above us, themselves toiling for wages from their higher-ups, and so on, and so on. but there CAN be. there HAS been, and there CAN be again. humans are social animals, with incredible cognitive potential; while some of our base instincts relish the thrill of competition, of ‚Äúwinning‚Äù, we also have the capacity to understand and work alongside one another to reach incredible goals. overcome the near-sightedness of what you know. search out others‚Äô experiences. research, ask questions, analyze, criticize, theorize. hope for a better future for the people of earth, and then act in whatever way you can to get us there. 

you don‚Äôt have to be content with what‚Äôs given to you. everybody deserves a chance to have all their needs met‚Äî to have food, water, shelter, community, freedom of movement and expression‚Äî without needing to prove that they‚Äôre more worthy of it than anyone else. that‚Äôs what being against capitalism is about.

author: @delicheese6774
text: That's something that has always confused me: marxism/communism are ideas that come from MODERNISM; they are not inherently related to postmodernism at all. In fact, since postmodernism covers such a wide range of ideas and positions, one of the only overarching statements that can be applied to postmodernism is the skepticism of meta-narratives; well it just so happens that marxism (dialectical materialism) IS a meta-narrative. This puts marxism and postmodernism directly at odds with each other...

author: @fkedupworld3833
text: Postmodernism is a very different set of ideas than anything that Karl Marx came up with. Postmodernism in the most simple of terms is the broad idea that there is nothing objective but rather everything is relative. Marxism, again very broadly, is a theory proposed by Karl Marx that all private property is inherently oppressive and the solution is the abolishment of private property. Very different Philosophies tackling mostly different topics.

replies.author: @Yotrymp
replies.text: Postmodernism is the foundation of modern far-leftism, while Marxism is one of its tools. They don't go hand-in-hand, but the nature of postmodernism makes it so Marxism can be ignored or used at will. Or see it like this: "the nature of postmodernism makes it so _______ can be ignored or used at will" where the blank can be filled with any temporary devotion to something for a gain in power. It's barely an ideology, and more of a mental disorder.

replies.author: @nathandrake5544
replies.text: Lol both you are wrong. Postmodernism isn't a philosophy so much as it is a phenomenon that philosophers wrote about. All of the postmodernists, even Derrida never posited that "nothing is objective;" rather, they questioned our ability to be objective because of the limitations of human perception. Postmodernism completely contradicts doctrinaire Marxism. The whole Marxist analysis of history is a grand historical narrative, and the postmodernist philosophers were skeptical of all historical narratives.

replies.author: @rhysf.505
replies.text:
"they questioned our ability to be objective because of the limitations of human perception." 

The problem is this is philosophy itself, not post-modernism. All of these questions go back as far as Plato and Aristotle. Philosophers through out all time have contemplated and attempted to define where the limits of our knowledge lie, the concept of acknowledging the permanent, however small, amount of uncertain underlying ALL of our knowledge was not invented with post-modernism, this is something that was understood long ago, this is was led to concept of Axioms which are the base levels of knowledge on which we have to build our understanding up from. The word Axiom goes back to ancient Greece so it's more than evident this it wasn't created by post-modernism. 

What the post-modernists did was assert that there is essentially no validity to the established axioms of previous philosophical eras, no more validity than those of other cultures in particular, as the post-modernists would focus on the fact that there are ingrained cultural norms, some of which are arbitrary, as evidence that the limits on our knowledge necessitate that everything we define as self-evident is more or less arbitrary, particularly when it comes to what many call "social constructs".

author: @Shinimusha
text:
I recently found you, because YouTube's algoritm has correctly identified me as the Marxist I am. I am a german political scientist that actually studied within the Frankfurt School. I really liked your Video, but there are a few points where I would want to correct you.
First, J√ºrgen Habermas is a direct student of Adorno, but they got beef because they had a hugely different few about the 68' movement. Habermas is kinda considered of a dumped down version and more of his own off-branch school.
Second, your statement about the DKP (Deutsche Kommunistische Partei, German Communist Party) and the Marxistisch Leninistische Partei Deutschlands (Marxist-Leninist Party of Germany) is kinda.. wrong. They themself are pretty small, that's true. But the KPD (Kommunistische Partei Deutschlands, Communist Party of Germany) which is kind of their spiritual successor was part of the first two Bundestage (Parliament of Post-War Germany). The SPD (Sozialdemokratische Partei Deutschlands, Social Democratic Party of Germany), which is one of our two big Parties in this Country has it's roots in a center left Marxist Movement as well. But those would not be counted today, they're really just considered center-center right now. More importantly, the Party I'm a member of is just called Die Linke "The Left" which is self-identified as "Democratic Soclaists". We're Marxists, some of us more then others. And we have 10% of the popular vote in this Country. Even the Green Party stil has a few self-proclaimed Marxists or Ex-Marxists.

Otherwise a pretty good video! Thanks, Subsribed :o

author: @envysart797
text:
Jordan Peterson does not know what post modernism is. Even people who are well versed in art and cultural academia have hard time defining what exactly post modernist means. 

I view it is a critique of ‚Äúmodernism‚Äù - which is itself a philosophy about breaking from the past and finding new forms of expression. So for one thing, conflating the modern with the traditional is tautology, modernism is about rejecting tradition at its core. So when JP derides the post modernists as being ‚Äúopposed to tradition‚Äù, and defending traditionalism as modern, he‚Äôs literally either confused or just full of shit. 

Ntm post modernists like Derrida, Dadaists and Marcel Duchamp had a key common point - the art and cultural establishments need to stop taking themselves seriously. And when you respond to a critique like that by saying that by being told to take yourself so seriously, that you are literally ‚Äúendangering western society‚Äù, and that art and cultural establishments are therefore the guardians of our whole civilisation, you‚Äôre just proving their point.

Here are one issue which would have been a great addition to 3 arrows video. What was Peterson's main criticism of postmodernism? Also, what was Habbermas criticism of postmodernism? There are lots of marxists that criticize postmodernism too, including the Frankfurt school. However there aren't a lot of postmodernist criticizing Marxism. Who criticized who isn't really important though, but why. What are their arguments? The arguments aren't usually because they are Jewish or French or Soviet or whatever, but for example: 
Postmodernism says there is an infinite interpretation of reality,  but then how many viable interpretations are there? Am i seeing colours in jungle or am I seeing a tiger ready to pounce on me? I think these are valid questions that 3 arrows didn't seem to address.

author: @Smhallways
text:
I would consider this the weakest essay I found on this channel. You ask for proof by asking where was it written down, where is the proof, etc. Yet the same logic would be quickly abandoned and turned 180 when discussing opposite issues, for example, systemic racism. When the opponents of systemic racism ask "show me where it is written down" then the argument goes that it doesn't matter what is de jure, but what are the actual effects. 
When people say USA is the greatest and most free, proof: Declaration of Independence says every man is equal - you would say it doesn't matter what it says. 
When Christians say religion is good, proof: Ten commandments - you would say it doesn't matter what they claim. 
When people say women have equal rights, proof: Every law written - you would say it doesn't matter what is written. 
Yet now your thesis on how Cultural Marxism is fake comes down to - there is no written proof. Now it becomes important what is written. Proof that you would not accept in other cases.

author: @airlesscanvas6425
text: Of course there was absolutely no mention of Antonio Gramsci, just conflation of cultural marxism and cultural bolshevism. To lay it out like this the main idea of Gramsci was that the reason the proletariat were not rising up like Marx predicted was because of the culture and it's various institution were keeping them servile. For Gramsci his solution for this was for socialists and other revolutionaries to infiltrate and subvert as many cultural and societal institutions as possible and to hollow them out. The goal of which was to cause enough agitation among the lower classes to make a communist uprising possible. Post-modernism in this case is simply a means to an end for the Marxist, a tool used to subvert out institutions and then to discard it when they take power.

replies.author: @jehaert
replies.text:
You missed the point. Noone said that every single song ion the world sounds the same, it is just about famous songs, songs in the charts, songs with billions of clicks on youtube, that stuff. Now I don't have decree in musical theory, but I daresay there was a bit more diversity a couple of decades back. 
Nowadways people are writing songs on a certain template (hook this long, chorus this long, all in all 2:38 cause that is the magic spot on spotify where people stop listening), just to get the clicks. They subdue their creativity even more to the idea of exploitation. 
One could also meantion the loudness war as an example for diminishing diversity.

author: @alandiaco
text: I laugh every time someone says that music today is simplistic and stupid. Boi, we've been using the same musical scales for 400 years, the friggin' piano was invented LITERALLY so it was easier to play EVERYTHING in C Major scale. THE NAMES ON THE NOTES were invented so it was easier to play in the C Major scale. Some pop songs out there, even absolutely mainstream ones, have an amazing harmonic and compositional complexity to them. People who claim that pop music is simple and basic "music-wise" either don't know the first thing about harmony and music theory, or have never sat down and analyzed pop songs.
